metadata.common_names: Flame Of The Forest, Royal Poinciana, Flamboyán

research_data.habitat_ai: Endemic to Madagascar's dry deciduous forests, specifically restricted to the western dry forests of Madagascar, including the north and west of the Bemaraha massif, dry forests around Antsiranana, and possibly Nosy Be
research_data.elevation_ranges_ai: From sea level up to about 1,000-2,000 meters in forests of warm humid areas
research_data.ecological_function_ai: Used to stabilize and enrich soil, grown on eroded sites for erosion control, and for soil rehabilitation
research_data.native_adapted_habitats_ai: Endemic to Madagascar's dry deciduous forests, now introduced to tropical and sub-tropical regions worldwide, endangered in its native habitat but naturalized in many introduced locations
research_data.agroforestry_use_cases_ai: Multipurpose tree used in agroforestry, cultivated as a shade tree in plantations, with uses including medicines, food, timber, fuel, and soil enrichment
research_data.conservation_status_ai: Classified as Vulnerable/Least Concern, with native populations threatened by charcoal production, slash-and-burn agriculture, grazing, and uncontrolled bush fires
research_data.general_description_ai: A medium-sized deciduous tree growing 9-15 meters tall, with fern-like leaves 30.5-50.8 cm long, featuring flame-colored flowers that bloom seasonally in midsummer
research_data.compatible_soil_types_ai: Tolerates many soil types from clay to sandy (prefers sandy soils), grows best in medium moisture, well-drained soils in full sun, with consistent moisture except during dry/dormant season
research_data.growth_form_ai: Umbrella-shaped, broad-spreading crown with long horizontal branches
research_data.leaf_type_ai: Compound (doubly pinnate) leaves with a feathery appearance, 30-50 cm long, with 20-40 pairs of primary leaflets, each divided into 10-20 pairs of secondary leaflets
research_data.deciduous_evergreen_ai: Almost evergreen, but deciduous in localities with long pronounced dry seasons
research_data.flower_color_ai: Bright red to orange-red flowers, 7-10 cm in diameter
research_data.fruit_type_ai: Green and flaccid when young, turning dark-brown and woody; legume-type pods up to 50 cm in length, 10 cm wide, containing up to 10 seeds
research_data.bark_characteristics_ai: Light brown to grayish-brown bark, smooth, with prominent lenticels, becoming slightly rough and fissured with age
research_data.stewardship_best_practices_ai: Plant in full sun with well-draining soil. The tree can grow in various soil conditions with good drainage, tolerating clay, loamy, sandy, or gravelly soil with pH between 4.9 and 10.6. Water regularly during spring, summer, and early fall, keeping soil moist but not soggy until roots are established. Apply balanced liquid fertilizer four to six weeks after planting, then two to three times per year for the first three years, with additional applications in early spring and fall.
research_data.planting_recipes_ai: Plant in a spacious location, as the tree can reach up to 40 feet tall and spread 40-70 feet wide. Avoid planting near walls, pavement, or structures it may overtake. After planting, cover soil with a 2-inch layer of mulch, leaving space near the trunk. For seed propagation: Soak seeds in hot water for 12-24 hours, plant about ½ inch deep in well-draining soil, maintain warm temperatures above 70°F, and expect germination within 7-14 days.
research_data.pruning_maintenance_ai: Prune to create a strong tree structure, as limbs are susceptible to breakage in high winds. Provide wind protection and form a strong branching structure. Prune in late winter or early spring before spring growth starts, focusing on major branches half the trunk's diameter or below 8-12 feet from the ground. Avoid excessive pruning to prevent reduced flowering.
research_data.disease_pest_management_ai: Common pests include spider mites (causing yellowing leaves), scales (attaching to stems and leaves), aphids, and caterpillars. Management strategies include: spraying with water, using insecticidal soap, applying neem oil, introducing beneficial insects like ladybugs, and manual removal of pests. Termites and shoot borers can damage the tree. The tree's seed oil has shown potential as a natural bio-pesticide, with research demonstrating effectiveness against termites, ticks, and cockroaches. Regular monitoring and preventive care, such as proper watering and pruning, can help keep the tree healthy and resistant to pests and diseases.
research_data.fire_management_ai: Highly heat-tolerant but sensitive to frost. Young trees are vulnerable to cold and may need protection when temperatures drop below 45°F (7°C). Mature trees can tolerate short periods of cold down to 25°F (-3°C) but may lose leaves or sustain damage near freezing. Thrives in dry, sunny conditions and is well-suited to tropical and subtropical climates.
research_data.cultural_significance_ai: Native to Madagascar, the Flamboyant (Delonix regia) is widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions as an ornamental tree. Its broad canopy provides excellent shade in landscapes, parks, and avenues. As a member of the Fabaceae family, it enhances soil fertility through nitrogen fixation. The tree has deep cultural significance: it is the state tree of Delhi, India, the national flower of St. Kitts and Nevis, and the city flower of Sepang, Malaysia. In Kerala, India, it has a religious legend associated with the crucifixion of Jesus Christ. The tree is also used in traditional medicine for various ailments and has been reported to have herbicide and antimicrobial properties.

Additional notable ecological insights:
- It is a non-nodulating legume
- Requires average annual temperatures of 14-26°C, precipitation of at least 700 mm, and can grow at altitudes from 0-2000 meters
- Has a shallow root system that competes with neighboring plants, so it should be planted away from other garden plants

data.stewardship_best_practices_ai: Plant in full sun with well-draining soil. The tree can grow in various soil conditions with good drainage, tolerating clay, loamy, sandy, or gravelly soil with pH between 4.9 and 10.6. Water regularly during spring, summer, and early fall, keeping soil moist but not soggy until roots are established. Apply balanced liquid fertilizer four to six weeks after planting, then two to three times per year for the first three years, with additional applications in early spring and fall.
data.planting_recipes_ai: Plant in a spacious location, as the tree can reach up to 40 feet tall and spread 40-70 feet wide. Avoid planting near walls, pavement, or structures it may overtake. After planting, cover soil with a 2-inch layer of mulch, leaving space near the trunk. For seed propagation: Soak seeds in hot water for 12-24 hours, plant about ½ inch deep in well-draining soil, maintain warm temperatures above 70°F, and expect germination within 7-14 days.
data.pruning_maintenance_ai: Prune to create a strong tree structure, as limbs are susceptible to breakage in high winds. Provide wind protection and form a strong branching structure. Prune in late winter or early spring before spring growth starts, focusing on major branches half the trunk's diameter or below 8-12 feet from the ground. Avoid excessive pruning to prevent reduced flowering.
data.disease_pest_management_ai: Common pests include spider mites (causing yellowing leaves), scales (attaching to stems and leaves), aphids, and caterpillars. Management strategies include: spraying with water, using insecticidal soap, applying neem oil, introducing beneficial insects like ladybugs, and manual removal of pests. Termites and shoot borers can damage the tree. The tree's seed oil has shown potential as a natural bio-pesticide, with research demonstrating effectiveness against termites, ticks, and cockroaches. Regular monitoring and preventive care, such as proper watering and pruning, can help keep the tree healthy and resistant to pests and diseases.
data.fire_management_ai: Highly heat-tolerant but sensitive to frost. Young trees are vulnerable to cold and may need protection when temperatures drop below 45°F (7°C). Mature trees can tolerate short periods of cold down to 25°F (-3°C) but may lose leaves or sustain damage near freezing. Thrives in dry, sunny conditions and is well-suited to tropical and subtropical climates.
data.cultural_significance_ai: Native to Madagascar, the Flamboyant (Delonix regia) is widely cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions as an ornamental tree. Its broad canopy provides excellent shade in landscapes, parks, and avenues. As a member of the Fabaceae family, it enhances soil fertility through nitrogen fixation. The tree has deep cultural significance: it is the state tree of Delhi, India, the national flower of St. Kitts and Nevis, and the city flower of Sepang, Malaysia. In Kerala, India, it has a religious legend associated with the crucifixion of Jesus Christ. The tree is also used in traditional medicine for various ailments and has been reported to have herbicide and antimicrobial properties.
